article.title: Bias and high-dimensional adjustment in observational studies of peer effects

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variation around the grand mean (dashed line) in panel A of Figure 1 indicate?
choices: The average probability of a user being exposed to a given URL.
The heterogeneity in the estimated propensity scores for exposed and unexposed user-URL pairs.
The distribution of actual sharing probabilities for the particular domain shown.
The relationship between the stratum number and the relative frequency of exposed pairs.

multiple_choice_question.text: In panel C of Figure 1, which line represents the naive observational estimate of the probability of sharing if not exposed (p(0))?
choices: Blue line
Green line
Grey line
Magenta line

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the closer alignment of the magenta line to the blue line in Panel C demonstrate?
choices: Exposed and unexposed users share URLs at similar rates.
Propensity score stratification improves the estimate of p(0) compared to ignoring stratification.
The probability of sharing is uniform across different strata.
The model perfectly predicts which user-URL pairs will result in sharing.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the y-axis in Panel B of Figure 2 represent?
choices: The estimated average treatment effect on the treated (ATT)
The relative percentage difference between the observational and experimental estimates of the relative risk
The absolute difference between the observational and experimental estimates of the risk difference
The estimated probability of sharing a URL if not exposed (p(0))

multiple_choice_question.text: Which model provides the least biased estimate of the relative risk of sharing a URL?
choices: Model D (demographics only)
Model AMs (all covariates + same domain sharing + other domain sharing)
Naive Model (stratified on domain only)
Model As (all base covariates + same domain sharing)

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the differences between the observational and experimental estimates of peer effects in this study?
choices: The use of different outcome measures in the observational and experimental analyses.
Differences in the populations sampled for the observational and experimental groups.
Confounding factors that influence both exposure to peers sharing URLs and individual sharing behavior.
The relatively small sample size of the experimental control group.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the estimated relative risk (RR) of sharing a URL when adjusting for all base covariates and same domain sharing (Model As)?
Which model produces the smallest estimate for the probability of sharing a URL if not exposed (p(0))?
choices: Model AMs
Model AM
Model As
Naive Model
The bias of all observational estimators is consistent across domains with different levels of prior popularity.
Adjusting for prior sharing behavior leads to greater bias reduction for URLs from domains with higher prior popularity.
The experimental estimate of the relative risk of sharing varies substantially depending on the prior popularity of the domain.
Only adjusting for demographic covariates is sufficient to reduce bias for URLs from domains with low prior popularity.
